item.title: Charity add a quote by Woody Allen
item.description: "To you, I'm an atheist. To God, I'm the loyal opposition." -- Woody Allen

item.title: Charity add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "You believe in a book that has talking animals, wizards, witches, demons, sticks turning into snakes, burning bushes, food falling from the sky, people walking on water, and all sorts of magical, absurd and primitive stories, and you say that we are the ones that need help?" -- Mark Twain

item.title: Charity add a quote by Philip Pullman
item.description: "I think it's perfectly possible to explain how the universe came about without bringing God into it, but I don't know everything, and there may well be a God somewhere, hiding away. Actually, if he is keeping out of sight, it's because he's ashamed of his followers and all the cruelty and ignorance they're responsible for promoting in his name. If I were him, I'd want nothing to do with them." -- Philip Pullman

item.title: Charity add a quote by Bill Maher
item.description:
"The problem is that the people with the most ridiculous ideas are always the people who are most certain of them."
(<i>The Decider</i>, July 21, 2007)" -- Bill Maher

item.title: Charity add a quote by Flannery O'Connor
item.description: "The truth does not change according to our ability to stomach it." -- Flannery O'Connor

item.title: Charity add a quote by Geraldine Brooks
item.description: "For to know a man's library is, in some measure, to know his mind." -- Geraldine Brooks

item.title: Charity add a quote by Harlan Ellison
item.description: "You are not entitled to your opinion. You are entitled to your <i>informed</i> opinion. No one is entitled to be ignorant." -- Harlan Ellison

item.title: Charity add a quote by Neil Gaiman
item.description: "[D]on't ever apologize to an author for buying something in paperback, or taking it out from a library (that's what they're there for. Use your library). Don't apologize to this author for buying books second hand, or getting them from bookcrossing or borrowing a friend's copy. What's important to me is that people read the books and enjoy them, and that, at some point in there, the book was bought by someone. And that people who like things, tell other people. The most important thing is that people read... " -- Neil Gaiman

item.title: Charity add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "I haven't any right to criticize books, and I don't do it except when I hate them. I often want to criticize Jane Austen, but her books madden me so that I can't conceal my frenzy from the reader; and therefore I have to stop every time I begin. Every time I read Pride and Prejudice I want to dig her up and beat her over the skull with her own shin-bone." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Charity add a quote by Anatole Broyard
item.description:
"The contents of someone's bookcase are part of his history, like an ancestral portrait."
(<i>About Books; Recoiling, Rereading, Retelling</i>, New York Times, February 22, 1987)" -- Anatole Broyard

item.title: Charity add a quote by Benjamin Franklin
item.description: "We are all born ignorant, but one must work hard to remain stupid." -- Benjamin Franklin

item.title: Charity add a quote by Nick Hornby
item.description: "Being a reader is sort of like being president, except reading involves fewer state dinners, usually. You have this agenda you want to get through, but you get distracted by life events, e.g., books arriving in the mail/World War III, and you are temporarily deflected from your chosen path." -- Nick Hornby

item.title: Charity add a quote by Michel de Montaigne
item.description: "To compensate a little for the treachery and weakness of my memory, so extreme that it has happened to me more than once to pick up again...books which I have read carefully a few years before. I have adopted the habit for some time now of adding at the end of each book the time I finished reading it and the judgment I have derived of it as a whole, so that this may represent to me at least the sense and general idea I had conceived of the author in reading it." -- Michel de Montaigne

item.title: Charity add a quote by Laurel Thatcher Ulrich
item.description: "Well-behaved women seldom make history." -- Laurel Thatcher Ulrich

item.title: Charity add a quote by John Wayne
item.description: "Life's hard. It's even harder when you're stupid." -- John Wayne

item.title: Charity add a quote by François Mitterrand
item.description: "A man loses contact with reality if he is not surrounded by his books." -- François Mitterrand

item.title: Charity add a quote by Germaine Greer
item.description: "Reading was my first solitary vice (and led to all others). I read while I ate, I read in the loo, I read in the bath. When I was supposed to be sleeping, I was reading." -- Germaine Greer

item.title: Charity add a quote by Aidan Chambers
item.description: "Few pleasures, for the true reader, rival the pleasure of browsing unhurriedly among books: old books, new books, library books, other people's books, one's own books - it does not matter whose or where. Simply to be among books, glancing at one here, reading a page from one over there, enjoying them all as objects to be touched, looked at, even smelt, is a deep satisfaction. And often, very often, while browsing haphazardly, looking for nothing in particular, you pick up a volume that suddenly excites you, and you know that this one of all the others you must read. Those are great moments - and the books we come across like that are often the most memorable." -- Aidan Chambers

item.title: Charity add a quote by Gabriel García Márquez
item.description: "The world must be all fucked up," he said then, "when men travel first class and literature goes as freight." -- Gabriel García Márquez

item.title: Charity add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "There are books of which the backs and covers are by far the best parts." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Charity add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "For most of history, Anonymous was a woman." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Charity add a quote by Henry Ward Beecherr
item.description: "Where is human nature so weak as in the bookstore?" -- Henry Ward Beecherr

item.title: Charity add a quote by Logan Pearsall Smith
item.description: "People say that life is the thing, but I prefer reading." -- Logan Pearsall Smith

item.title: Charity add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "Education: the path from cocky ignorance to miserable uncertainty." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Charity add a quote by Douglas Coupland
item.description: "TV and the Internet are good because they keep stupid people from spending too much time out in public." -- Douglas Coupland

item.title: Charity add a quote by F.L. Lucas
item.description: "It seems to me as natural and necessary to keep notes, however brief, of one's reading, as logs of voyages or photographs of one's travels. For memory, in most of us, is a liar with galloping consumption." -- F.L. Lucas

item.title: Charity add a quote by Marilyn Monroe
item.description: "Who said nights were for sleep?" -- Marilyn Monroe

item.title: Charity add a quote by Aldous Huxley
item.description: "Facts do not cease to exist because they are ignored." -- Aldous Huxley

item.title: Charity add a quote by Mahatma Gandhi
item.description: "An eye for an eye will only make the whole world blind." -- Mahatma Gandhi

item.title: Charity add a quote by Frank Zappa
item.description: "I think it is good that books still exist, but they do make me sleepy." -- Frank Zappa
